note.body: This looks like I intended to also add an ellipsis if the last line to fit vertically was in fact empty (this indeed happened a bunch when limiting posts' height in Tuba with `GtkLabel:nat-lines`), but something about `fabricate_initial_empty_span`/`_pango_layout_line_ellipsize` wasn't yet handling the empty line cases properly, so I commented it out.

target_title: Improve ellipsization

note.body: Runs and items are the same thing. A normal run is a sequence of text that has uniform script / language / font / etc, so we can make a shape() call for it. The 'ellipsization run' that is created in ellipsize.c is a bit special in that we don't care about this uniformity, since we're only going to shape for it ... anyway.

target_title: Improve ellipsization

note.body:
Replacing `line_of_par` with `is_paragraph_start` + `is_last_paragraph` is a mostly independent change which makes it so that the limit on the number of lines is per-layout rather than per-paragraph. So it should go into a separate commit at least.

The `set_height ()` docs had a clause about this being a possible change since forever, but it's still a compatibility break, in that previously the default height of -1 acted as if the new `PANGO_WRAP_NONE` was used, instead of limiting the whole layout to a single line.

target_title: Improve ellipsization

note.body:
This is the part that I hoped you would take a closer look at / rewrite entirely. Because I don't fully understand what's going on here (and I must admit I still don't fully understand what "runs" and "items" are either), nor do I have any experience with non-LTR languages / ones that require complex shaping.

From what I remember, it always replaced some part of the line with an ellipsis, even though an ellipsis would fit without trimming anything. It's the latter that I wanted to achieve.

That being said, if the last line ends on punctuation (period being the most common case), it would likely look more natural if we do trim it away before appending ellipsis. So there should be some logic for handling that case.

That's for

> when inline content overflows its end line box edge in the inline progression direction of its block container element ("the block")

meaning, as MDN, explains it,

> The text-overflow property only affects content that is overflowing a block container element in its inline progression direction (not text overflowing at the bottom of a box, for example).

But it's the latter case we're interested in here.

note.body:
The `no_more_lines` / `after_paragraph_layout` thing in particular is an attempt to fix the issue with log attrs, which is that we're only filling them while laying out lines, so we stop once we hit the height limit. Yet `layout->log_attrs` remains set, so `need_log_attrs = FALSE` on the next run, which may be for a different width/height.

I should file a proper issue report about that.

> It might look a bit odd to have ... at the end of a paragraph.

Indeed, but is doing nothing better than that? What do other platforms do?

target_title: layout: Differentiate ellipsized and truncated

note.body:
OK, here's what I had: https://gitlab.gnome.org/-/snippets/6745 (Ignore `pango_layout_render_to_png`, that's just a local development aid, very handy to call from GDB to visualize layouts.)

In particular, this tried to actually force the last line that did fit to get ellipsized if there is more text following that did not fit, whether in the same paragraph or not. Whereas this MR cements it in the public API that Pango will not ellipsize in that case.

I do think that ellipsizing if more lines won't fit into the height limit makes a lot of sense, at least in user interfaces: that's how we communicate to the user that there is further text, no matter if there was a `\n` in the text where the available height happened to run out.

note.body:
I can reproduce the dotted circle with `hb-shape` when setting the script to `deva`:
```
$ hb-shape NotoSans-Regular.ttf "₂ ₃ ₁" --script=deva --no-positions -V
trace: start preprocess-text	buffer: <U+2082=0|U+0020=1|U+2083=2|U+0020=3|U+2081=4>
trace: end preprocess-text	buffer: <U+2082=0|U+0020=1|U+2083=2|U+0020=3|U+2081=4>
...
trace: start reordering indic initial	buffer: [uni2082=0|space=1|uni2083=2|space=3|uni2081=4]
trace: start inserting dotted-circles	buffer: [uni2082=0|space=1|uni2083=2|space=3|uni2081=4]
trace: end inserting dotted-circles	buffer: [uni25CC=0|uni2082=0|space=1|uni25CC=2|uni2083=2|space=3|uni2081=4]
trace: end reordering indic initial	buffer: [uni25CC=0|uni2082=0|space=1|uni25CC=2|uni2083=2|space=3|uni2081=4]
...
[uni25CC=0|uni2082=0|space=1|uni25CC=2|uni2083=2|space=3|uni2081=4]
```

So the dotted circle is inserted by the Indic shaper before subscript 2 and 3 if not preceded by an Indic character, but subscript 1. This is a HarfBuzz issue.

note.body:
Ok, so I dug a little deeper.

Building ghostty with `-fsys=fontconfig` (to make it use system fontconfig library v2.15 instead of a vendored one v2.14) makes it work.
It looks like pango tries to use `FcPatternGetString()` function from a `ghostty` binary instead of using the dynamic library. The one from v2.14 always returns `false` when called with `FC_FONT_WRAPPER` as an object, as expected.

note.body:
@matthiasc well, seems that I was wrong.

After reading https://github.com/googlefonts/noto-emoji/blob/main/Makefile I see that it builds fonts only from png, not svg.

Thus, OpenBSD hasn't got libpng in its base and this mean that freetype is built without png support.

So, it is expected I think that no support of color emoji at freetype.

But Qt application, somehow, managed to show it.

target_title: memory leak in 'pango_markup_parser_new_internal' failure path

note.body:
We create a GMarkupContext, and we give it the MarkupData as user data,
with the destroy_markup_data function to free it. And destroy_markup_data frees both md->text and md->attr_list.

Unless you have clear evidence that there is a leak here, this should all be taken care of.

If there was a bug, it would be GMarkupParseContext not calling the destroy notify, but that is extremely
unlikely.

note.body:
I don't quite know the file getting used (apparently none) when things crash - specially I don't quite know how to get information beyond `<unknown filename>`.
`fonts-symbola` package has following contents:
```
$ dpkg-query -L fonts-symbola
/.
/usr
/usr/share
/usr/share/doc
/usr/share/doc/fonts-symbola
/usr/share/doc/fonts-symbola/changelog.Debian.gz
/usr/share/doc/fonts-symbola/copyright
/usr/share/fonts
/usr/share/fonts/truetype
/usr/share/fonts/truetype/ancient-scripts
/usr/share/fonts/truetype/ancient-scripts/Symbola_hint.ttf
```
I also checked out `fc-list` and grepped for symbola:
```
$ fc-list | grep -i symbola
/usr/share/fonts/truetype/noto/NotoSansSymbols2-Regular.ttf: Symbola,Noto Sans Symbols2:style=Regular
Symbola:style=Regular
```
I guess the second entry without any file name might be the root cause and I'll investigate more wrt what is the configuration for fontconfig leading to this result.

All that said, I feel with any configuration and/or corrupted font, libpango shouldn't segfault - at least as long as libfontconfig is not doing anything wrong outside of its API contract (I'm assuming a returned `FcResult` can be a `NULL`).
If you feel we shouldn't handle the segfault, I'll close the request and also update the original issue that I opened.

note.body:
I've used test case from @afalkenhahn which I build on my OpenBSD laptop as:
```
cc -I/usr/local/include -I/usr/X11R6/include/freetype2 -I/usr/local/include/pango-1.0 -I/usr/local/include/glib-2.0 -I/usr/local/lib/glib-2.0/include -I/usr/local/include/harfbuzz -I/usr/local/include/cairo -I/usr/X11R6/include -L/usr/local/lib -lcairo -lpango-1.0 -lpangocairo-1.0 -lgobject-2.0 test.c
```
and it doesn't render emoji as well.

Unfortently trick with `pango_cairo_font_map_new_for_font_type` doesn't work here.

I'm using pango `1.54.0` and it can't render emoji not via test script, not via `
pango-view --text "Test 😊"`. I've tried to enforce used font via `pango-view --text "Test 😊" --font="Noto Color Emoji" ` without any effect.

When I run test program at `ktrace`, I can see via `kdump` that it loads fonts with emoji:
```
tmp $ kdump | grep '.ttf'
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF/DejaVuSans.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/local/share/fonts/noto/NotoColorEmoji.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF/DejaVuSans.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF/DejaVuSans.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/local/share/fonts/noto/NotoColorEmoji.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/local/share/fonts/noto/NotoColorEmoji.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF/DejaVuSans.ttf"
 49474 a.out    NAMI  "/usr/local/share/fonts/noto/NotoColorEmoji.ttf"
tmp $ 
```

I've discovered this issue with attempt to dig why I haven't see any emoji on Gtk applications on OpenBSD, when Qt and Xterm works well.

Thus, here almost two year old email where is confirmed that emoji is broken: https://marc.info/?l=openbsd-ports&m=167672760824204&w=2

note.body:
Indeed you're right. It seems I'm missing something here. Let me try to explain how I'm debugging this thing. I had setup a conditional breakpoint at my `fonts.c:1796 if coverage==0`. That line is from `pango_font_default_has_char` with:
```
1796      PangoCoverageLevel result = pango_coverage_get (coverage, wc);
```
I then continued with steps to reproduce the issue. Once the breakpoint hit, I did `tbreak -1` followed by `jump -1` to attempt to re-invoke line 1795 with:
```
1795      PangoCoverage *coverage = pango_font_get_coverage (font, pango_language_get_default ());
```
My assertion of `font` being `NULL` was from this re-invocation. I think the method I'm using is flawed. Currently, I'm at a bit of loss on how to break at L1795 at its correct first invocation. I'm trying to avoid a brute force to continue checking that call because it does get called quite a few times before the call that faults.
Any tips would be helpful.

target_title: SIGSEGV during layout calculation with Symbola font

note.body:
font being NULL seems implausible. Your stacktrace shows:

```
get_font_foreach 
    pango_font_default_has_char
        pango_coverage_get
```

And looking at the code of get_font_foreach, the first thing it does is:

```
  if (G_UNLIKELY (!font))
    return FALSE;
```

Hi,

I couldn't reproduce this Cairo error on my system, sadly, with or without Cantarell fonts installed (version 0.303).  I do agree that we should load the custom fonts into our fontmap first, before the system ones, so I will open an MR for that shortly.  The glyph ID I had for all cases for 'a' was 244; can't say about the FontConfig items though.

What I got with Cantarell fonts 0.303 installed:
```
<snip>

#   .height =  9587
#

#   .y = -14763

#   .height =  18022
#
# },

#

#

#   .x_bearing = -0.310667 (== -318)
#   .y_bearing = -8.216000 (== -8413)
#   .width = 7.720000 (== 7905)
#   .height = 9.362666 (== 9587)
#   .x_advance = 7.509334 (== 7690)
#   .y_advance = 0.000000 (== 0)
#
```
In case one may be interested, Cairo was built with FreeType support but no FontConfig support.

With blessings, and cheers!

note.body:
I gave bad advice. The function to call before fork is pango_cairo_set_default_font_map (NULL).

This assumes that the fontmap isn't explictly stored somewhere.

Here is a working example:

[test-fork.c](/uploads/eb5bb3e575265ded931a735cbbd38334/test-fork.c)

If you comment out the pango_cairo_set_default_font_map call, the child will block in pango and the parent will wait forever in waitpid()

target_title: Segfault inside libdex fiber
Segfault inside libdex fiber

note.body:
The issue here is just that you ran out of stack space and hit the guard page. The default stack size (0) was specified so it's only 64-kb for the fiber. Using a larger stack size resolves the issue.

But we may still want to figure out who is requesting that much stack space and if it would be better to do that on the heap instead. My general rule is no more than 1 page worth of data as `alloca()`

note.body:
I'll take a look.

There really shouldn't be anything special in this case. It's a fiber which is driven by a callback from a GSource in the GMainContext of the main thread.

The fiber shares TLS with the main thread and is a "linked stack" similarly to what you'd see with a signal stack.

> Which gnuplot process uses pango, the parent or the child?

In the `ltrace -f` output (note that the issue does not occur in this case, because it is too slow), I can see pango calls only in the main process (there is no child yet: all these calls are done before the fork).

single fontconfig thread introduces a hang in pango_fc_patterns_get_font_pattern (affecting gnuplot)

note.body:
Note that the gnuplot code does not contain any explicit reference to `exit_group`, and the `exit_group(0)` is just a consequence of `exit(0)` (as shown by a simple `strace` test on `int main (void) { exit (0); }`), which should be safe.

According to [this Stack Overflow answer to "Is it bad practice to create a thread in a shared library?"](https://stackoverflow.com/a/27304253/3782797), (shared) libraries should avoid creating threads, so that the change in Pango should be reverted. But if this is really needed, this must be documented in the API, and I would also say that something should be done so that the new API cannot be used by unaware applications, and the API should ensure that the `exit` function can be called safely. Note also that in such a case since this modifies the behavior of the library, this would be an ABI breakage too.
